Supervised Learning vs Unsupervised Learning

Supervised or Unsupervisedimage source: Ma Yan, et al
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 2. Statistical Prediction and Supervised Learning
text:
Regularization


Loss function \[L(\vec{\beta}) = \text{argmin}_{\vec{\beta}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \left(y_{i} - \beta_{0} - \sum_{j=1}^{k} \beta_{j}x_{ij}\right)^{2}\]
L1 Regularization \[L(\vec{\beta}, \lambda) = \text{argmin}_{\vec{\beta}} \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} \left(y_{i} - \beta_{0} - \sum_{j=1}^{k} \beta_{j}x_{ij}\right)^{2} + \lambda\sum_{j=i}^{k}|\beta_{j}|\right]\]
L2 Regularization \[L(\vec{\beta}, \lambda) = \text{argmin}_{\vec{\beta}} \left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} \left(y_{i} - \beta_{0} - \sum_{j=1}^{k} \beta_{j}x_{ij}\right)^{2} + \lambda\sum_{j=i}^{k}\beta_{j}^{2}\right]\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 2. Statistical Prediction and Supervised Learning
text:
Empirical Risk Minimization
We can approximate the expected risk over a loss function, data set, and hypothesis model \(h\)
\[\text{E}\left[L((\vec{x}, \vec{y}), h)\right]\] by taking the average over the training data
\[\frac{1}{n}\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n} L((x_{i}, y_{i}), h)\] * formulas outlined by Professor Alexander Jung
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 2. Statistical Prediction and Supervised Learning
text:
Bias-Variance Tradeoff
Within a hypothesis class of similar modeling functions, we are concerned with the bias-variance tradeoff in model selection.

bias-variance tradeoffimage source: Scott Fortmann-Roe
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 2. Statistical Prediction and Supervised Learning
text:
Linear Foundations
“For more complex and high-dimensional problems with potential nonlinear dependencies between features, it’s often useful to ask:

What’s a linear model for the problem?
Why does the linear model fail?
What’s the best way to add nonlinearity, given the semantic structure of the problem?
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

areas for artificial intelligenceimage source: RapidOps

title: 1. Preliminaries
text:
Math Topics


Gradients and their relation to local minima/maxima
The chain rule for differentiation
Matrices as linear transformations for vectors
Notions of basis/rank/span/independence/etc.



calculus
linear algebra

title: Welcome
text:
This is a companion for the book Generative AI Handbook by William Brown (copyright June 5, 2024).
Each chapter title to the left is a link to a slide deck.

These slides are being developed by this club.
Each deck will open in its own tab.
You may want to type “s” at the start of each deck to open the speaker notes.
Join the Data Science Learning Community to participate in the discussion!

We follow the Data Science Learning Community Code of Conduct.

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
text:
Regret
\[\text{Regret}_{T}(A) = \text{sup}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(x_{t}^{A}) - \text{min}_{x}\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(x)\right]\]

\(\vec{x}_{t}^{A}\): player actions of an algorithm in a decision set
\(T\): number of game iterations
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
text:
Applications

spam filtering
path finding
portfolio selection
recommendation systems
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
text:
Experts and Adversaries
Theorem 1.2 Let \(\epsilon\in(0,0.5)\). Suppose that the best expert makes \(L\) mistakes. Then:

\(\exists\) an efficient deterministic algorithm \(< 2(1+\epsilon)L + \frac{2\log N}{\epsilon}\) mistakes
\(\exists\) an efficient randomized algorithm \(\leq (1+\epsilon)L + \frac{\log N}{\epsilon}\) mistakes
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
text:
Weighted Majority Algorithm

predict according to majority of experts

\[a_{t} = \begin{cases} A, & W_{t}(A) \geq W_{t}(B) \\ B, & \text{otherwise}\end{cases}\]

update weights

\[W_{t+1}(i) = \begin{cases}W_{t}(i), & \text{if expert i was correct} \\ W_{t}(i)(1-\epsilon), & \text{if expert i was wrong}\end{cases}\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 4. Online Learning and Regret Minimization
text:
Hedging
\[W_{t+1}(i) = W_{t}(i)e^{-\epsilon \ell_{t}(i)}\]

\(\epsilon\): learning rate
\(\ell_{t}(i)\): loss by expert \(i\) at iteration \(t\)
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 6. Markov Models
text:
Markov Property
The future of a stochastic process is independent of its past
\[P(X_{t+1} = x|X_{t}, X_{t-1}, ..., X_{t-k}) = P(X_{t+1} = x|X_{t})\] * memoryless property
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: Club Meetings
text:
Book club meetings

Volunteer leads discussion of a chapter

This is the best way to learn the material.

Presentations:

Review of material
Questions you have
Maybe live demo

More info about editing: this github repo.
Recorded, available on the Data Science Learning Community YouTube Channel (DSLC.video).

title: Club Meetings
text:
Pace

Goal: 3 chapters/week
Ok to split overwhelming chapters
Ok to combine short chapters
Meet every week except holidays, etc

Ideally can discuss even if presenter unavailable

title: Club Meetings
text:
Learning objectives (LOs)

Students who study with LOs in mind retain more.
Tips:

“After today’s session, you will be able to…”
Very roughly 1 per section.

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Textbook





Sutton and Barto








Mutual Information
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Objective

policy: \(\pi(a|s)\)
return: \(G_{t} = \sum_{k=t+1}^{T} \gamma^{k-t-1}R_{k}\)
maximize expected return over all policies

\[\text{max}_{\pi} \text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}]\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Coupled Equations

state value function

\[v_{\pi}(s) = \text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}|S_{t} = s]\]

action value function

\[q_{\pi}(s,a) = \text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}|S_{t} = s, A_{t} = a]\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Bellman Equations

connect all state values

\[\begin{array}{rcl}
  v_{\pi}(s^{i}) & = & \text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}|s^{i}] \\
  ~ & = & \sum_{\{a\}} \pi(a|s^{i}) \cdot q(s^{i},a) \\
  ~ & = & \sum_{\{a\}} \pi(a|s^{i}) \cdot \text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}|s^{i}, a] \\
\end{array}\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Bellman Optimality Equations
For any optimal \(\pi_{*}\), \(\forall s \in S\), \(\forall a \in A\)
\[\begin{array}{rcl}
  v_{*}(s) & = & \text{max}_{a} q_{*}(s,a) \\
  q_{*}(s,a) & = & \sum_{s,r} p(s'r|s,a)[r + \gamma v_{*}(s')] \\
\end{array}\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Monte Carlo Methods
We do not know \(p(s'r|s,a)\)

generate samples: \(S_{0}, A_{0}, R_{1}, S_{1}, A_{1}, R_{2}, ...\)
obtain averages \(\approx\) expected values
generalized policy iteration to obtain

\[\pi \approx \pi_{*}\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Monte Carlo Evaluation

approx \(v_{\pi}(s)\)

\[\text{E}_{\pi}[G_{t}|S_{t} = s] \approx \frac{1}{C(s)}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sum_{\tau=0}^{T_{m}-1} I(s_{\tau}^{m} = s)g_{\tau}^{m}\] * step size \(\alpha\) for update rule
\[V(s_{t}^{m}) \leftarrow V(s_{t}^{m}) + \alpha\left(g_{t}^{m} - V(s_{t}^{m})\right)\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Exploration-Exploitation Trade-Off

to discover optimal policies


we must explroe all state-action pairs


to get high returns


we must exploit known high-value pairs
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Example: Blackjack

MCMC solving blackjack gameimage credit: Mutual Information

10 million games played
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Temporal Difference Learning

Markov Reward Process: A Markov decision process, but w/o actions
MCMC requires an episode to complete before updating


but what if an episode is long?
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
n-step TD
Replace \(g_{t}^{m}\) with
\[g_{t:t+n}^{m} = r_{t+1}^{m} + \gamma r_{t+2}^{m} + \cdots + \gamma^{n-1} r_{t+n}^{m} + \gamma_{n}V(s_{t+n}^{m})\]

updates are applied during the episoes with an n-step delay
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Advantages
Compared to MC, TD has

batch training
\(V(s)\) do not depend on stepsize \(\alpha\)
max likelihood of MRP (instead of min MSE)
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Q-Learning
\[r_{t+1}^{m} + \gamma \text{max}_{a} Q(s_{t+1}^{m},a)\]
updates \(Q\) after each sarsa tuple (each n-step delay)
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Toward Continuity

previous methods assumed tabular (discrete) and finite state spaces
without “infinite data”, can we still generalize?
function approximation: supervised learning + reinforcement learning
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Parameter Space
\[v_{\pi}(s) \approx \hat{v}(s,w), \quad w \in \mathbb{R}^{d}\] * caution: updating \(w\) updates many values of \(s\)

not just the “visited states”
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Value Error
\[\text{VE}(w) = \sum_{s \in S} \mu(s)\left[v_{\pi}(s) - \hat{v}(s,w)\right]^{2}\]

\(\mu\): distribution of states
solve with stochastic gradient descent

\[w \leftarrow w + \alpha\left[U_{t} - \hat{v}(S_{t},w)\right] \nabla \hat{v}(S_{t},w)\]
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction

title: 5. Reinforcement Learning
text:
Target Selection
To find target \(U_{t}\)

may have multiple local minima
estimates for state values may be biased
employ Semi-Gradient Temporal Difference
crumbs: Section I: Foundations of Sequential Prediction
